awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Biophysical and Molecular Mechanisms of Ultrafast Endocytosis at Neuronal Synapses
awd_abstract_narration:
Physical forces determine how the membrane of a living cell changes shape.  Endocytosis is a membrane process that is essential for bringing molecules into the cell.  Viruses often gain entry into cells by hijacking the endocytic process, and thus it is critical to understand how physical forces contribute to membrane remodeling and, specifically, to endocytosis. One place where endocytosis is important is in the transfer of packets of material from one nerve cell to another at a nerve synapse.  How this type of endocytosis occurs remains a mystery. Recent experiments have discovered a novel, ultrafast, endocytic mechanism at  synapses that occurs within 50 milliseconds. The mechanisms underlying the ultrafast endocytosis, however, remain poorly understood. The goal of this project is to gain mechanistic insights into this novel endocytic pathway. Since defects in endocytosis at nerve synapses may cause neurodegenerative diseases, the work will lay the foundation to understand synapses in different diseases.  To educate citizens and attract young people into science research, the investigators will create opportunities for high-school students to participate in research-based scientific activities, deliver guest lectures about the research at high schools and host high school teachers in the lab.

In this research, we will take synergistic experimental and computer modeling approaches to test these models. The Watanabe lab will perform localization and perturbation experiments to reveal the molecular organization and requirements. The Agrawal lab will use the molecular information to build computational modeling to test the passive and active mechanisms and predict the time-scales. The proposed work will be the first unified effort to investigate vesicle dynamics regulated by elastic and dissipative forces. In addition, the proposed research will provide a validated modeling framework for future exploration of membrane-protein dynamics and cellular interface remodeling.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: The research objective of this project was to understand membrane-protein interactions in neurons and neuronal synapses. Our research offers the following new insights. First, it provides evidence of tension sensitivity in a membrane remodeling protein that participates in cellular transport, and shows that lipids can assist fission proteins by remodeling membrane. Second, it shows that selective lipids are able to locally aggregate around proteins and impact protein configuration and stability. Our studies give insights into potential mechanisms by lipids can modulate gating of voltage-sensitive channels. Another study shows that lipids can stabilize peptide-receptor interactions. Third, it shows that lateral electric field can polarize the bilayer and shift its phase transition temperature. Till date, the majority of the studies in the literature have focussed on quantifying the effect of normal electric fields. Our work will catalyze future studies to investigate the influence of lateral electric field in remodeling cellular bilayers and regulating lipid-protein interactions. The grant has also contributed to the development of a new computational framework to model complex membrane-protein dynamics.

Broader Impact: The findings from these project would be valuable in investigating the mechanics of cellular transport and signaling in electrically-active cells. Our findings can help gain new insights into the mechanics and treatment of neurological disorders. Our work on lateral electric field-bilayer interaction can provide new mechanistic insights into phenomena such as wound healing. The project has supported several graduate students towards the fulfillment of their PhD research at the University of Houston. It has also contributed to outreach activities at local schools and in the training of undergraduate students. The findings from the research have been disseminated through scholarly journals, and conference posters and presentations.


Last Modified: 12/16/2021
Modified by: Ashutosh Agrawal
